articles.headline: Nowadays, Angola Is Oil’s Topic A
articles.snippet: Exxon Mobil, Chevron, BP and others have poured billions into Angola in the last decade to unlock petroleum resources, and the payoffs are finally coming in.
articles.abstract: Exxon Mobil, Chevron, BP and others have poured billions into Angola in the last decade to unlock petroleum resources, and the payoffs are finally coming in.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA, March 16 — Angola, which shared the stage with the world’s most powerful oil-producing nations at its first OPEC meeting here Thursday, is an unlikely candidate to be the darling of the global oil industry.

articles.headline: For G.O.P., First Stop on ’08 Trail Is Hotbed of Immigration Politics
articles.snippet: The issue of how to deal with illegal immigrants is causing particular complications for Senator John McCain.
articles.abstract: The issue of how to deal with illegal immigrants is causing particular complications for Senator John McCain.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, March 17 — Immigration, an issue that has divided Republicans in Washington, is reverberating across the party’s presidential campaign field, causing particular complications for Senator John McCain of Arizona.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Fights Back Over Firings
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart filed a legal brief on Monday directly contradicting the statements of two former marketing officials who were fired late last year.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart filed a legal brief on Monday directly contradicting the statements of two former marketing officials who were fired late last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart asserted yesterday in a court filing that two of its former top marketing officials had engaged in a sexual relationship during the process of selecting new advertising agencies and had sought jobs with one of the agencies they ultimately recommended.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: I.R.S. Agents Feel Pressed to End Cases
articles.snippet: Auditors complain that they are being forced to close corporate cases prematurely, allowing billions in tax dollars to go unpaid.
articles.abstract: Auditors complain that they are being forced to close corporate cases prematurely, allowing billions in tax dollars to go unpaid.
articles.lead_paragraph: The head of the Internal Revenue Service faces questions in Congress today about auditors’ complaints that they are being forced to close corporate cases prematurely, allowing billions in tax dollars to go unpaid.

articles.headline: Army Brigade Finds Itself Stretched Thin
articles.snippet: The declining readiness of the First Brigade of the 82nd Airborne Division is a sign of the Iraq war’s toll.
articles.abstract: The declining readiness of the First Brigade of the 82nd Airborne Division is a sign of the Iraq war’s toll.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT POLK, La., March 14 — For decades, the Army has kept a brigade of the 82nd Airborne Division on round-the-clock alert, poised to respond to a crisis anywhere in 18 to 72 hours.

articles.headline: Court Rejects Suit Against Enron Banks
articles.snippet: The decision stymies any mass effort by shareholders to recoup $40 billion in losses from Wall Street banks that had earned fees from Enron.
articles.abstract: The decision stymies any mass effort by shareholders to recoup $40 billion in losses from Wall Street banks that had earned fees from Enron.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel ruled yesterday that a class-action lawsuit against investment banks over their role as advisers to Enron cannot go ahead, dealing a blow to shareholders who lost billions of dollars after the company collapsed in 2001.

articles.headline: Russia Gives Iran Ultimatum on Enrichment
articles.snippet: Russia said it will withhold nuclear fuel unless Iran suspends its uranium enrichment as demanded by the Security Council.
articles.abstract: Russia said it will withhold nuclear fuel unless Iran suspends its uranium enrichment as demanded by the Security Council.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 19 — Russia has informed Iran that it will withhold nuclear fuel for Iran’s nearly completed Bushehr power plant unless Iran suspends its uranium enrichment as demanded by the United Nations Security Council, European, American and Iranian officials say.

articles.headline: Money Looms in Episcopalian Rift With Anglicans
articles.snippet: The Episcopal Church bankrolls much of the Anglican Communion’s operations, making severing ties difficult.
articles.abstract: The Episcopal Church bankrolls much of the Anglican Communion’s operations, making severing ties difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: As leaders of the Anglican Communion hold meeting after meeting to debate severing ties with the Episcopal Church in the United States for consecrating an openly gay bishop, one of the unspoken complications is just who has been paying the bills.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Neela Banerjee

articles.headline: Airbus Superjumbo Takes a Lap Around America
articles.snippet: The world’s largest passenger plane, plagued by delays, will stop at several American airports this week.
articles.abstract: The world’s largest passenger plane, plagued by delays, will stop at several American airports this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all its troubles, the double-decker superjumbo Airbus A380 is enjoying a star turn in the aviation world spotlight.
